pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [91e9d09be1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17000/commits/91e9d09be1d5b146172bb2ca9e37dbf25cbefb00)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.Fermat`|676|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ coprime_fermat_fermat`
`+ fermat`
`+ fermat_eq_prod_add_two`
`+ fermat_one`
`+ fermat_product`
`+ fermat_two`
`+ fermat_zero`
`+ odd_fermat`
`+ strictMono_fermat`
`+ two_lt_fermat`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
What is the relation of this PR with #14874?

> What is the relation of this PR with #14874?

I was not aware of that, but the results are different. 
Happy to rebase is either way. I think for #14874 it would be good if they used the terminology introduced here.
Thanks for the review, @loefflerd!

Thanks for your patience with all these pedantic formatting corrections! I think this is good to go now

maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

:v: mo271 can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

bors r+

(I swear I didn't make it the round number on purpose, it was just a coincident. Perhaps I should have waited for the next Fermat number #65537.)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11269796390/job/31339133245)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11269796390/job/31339133851)

Nice work and congratulations on the round number!

bors d+
Congrats on getting number 17,000! Here's some initial remarks.
This is good material to have. I've left some minor suggestions; happy to recommend merging once those are applied.
Here are the last couple of (very pedantic) corrections.

Nice work and congratulations on the round number!

bors d+

```suggestion
def fermat (n : ℕ) : ℕ := 2 ^ (2 ^ n) + 1
```

Since these are pretty trivial lemmas I think it's fine to have them grouped together like this:
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem fermat_zero : fermat 0 = 3 := rfl
@[simp] theorem fermat_one : fermat 1 = 5 := rfl
@[simp] theorem fermat_two : fermat 2 = 17 := rfl
```

```suggestion
## Main theorems

- `coprime_fermat_fermat`: two distinct fermat numbers are coprime.
-/

open Nat
```

a) Does this make sense as a `simp` lemma? I can't imagine you're going to come across the LHS much, even within this file.
b) I'd imagine `fermat_eq_prod_add_two` is the more useful lemma, since it avoids natural subtraction (and it's the one you use for `coprime_fermat_fermat`).

a) not super sure, but it seems to be a somewhat simple lhs. For the next lemma in this file, we could use this simp. But I'm happy to remove it if you think
b) yeah, since I use `fermat_product` in the proof anyhow, I thought I might as well give it a name.
I also think this shouldn't be `simp`.
removed `simp`

I hadn't ever heard of this name for this theorem, and Google seems to have the same opinion - every single result I'm finding is for Goldbach's conjecture instead. Is this name used in any literature?

it is mentioned in wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_number
and here
https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Goldbach%27s_Theorem
A search for "Goldbach's theorem" fermat numbers also give many books
Is this a more useful statement than `3 ≤ fermat n`?

I think both are equally useful, but having both seems like an overkill. I added this one, because I though `fermat n - 2` might appear in more than one theorem on fermat numbers and this way, one can easily remove the nat subtraction, but of course it would also be easy to do that if three_le_fermat was present.

```suggestion
theorem fermat_eq_prod_add_two {n : ℕ} : fermat n = (∏ k in Finset.range n, fermat k) + 2 := by
```

```suggestion
  · rfl
```
`juskevic` is probably a better romanisation of the name, the other v's are diacritics
good point, fixed
I think using LaTeX in module / declaration docstrings should be avoided unless absolutely necessary.

ok, fixed. 
When I wrote the docstring I looked a the doc string for the Bernoulli numbers and there is lots of latex

The Bernoulli file has some much more complicated formulae (which would become unreadable when squashed onto one line). That doesn't apply here. Please kill the remaining `$` signs and put formulae in backticks `2^(2^n) + 1` etc.
"Fermat" should be capitalized in general text (i.e. when not part of a declaration name)
sure, fixed

```suggestion
  · simpa only [coprime_comm] using this h.symm (by omega)
```

```suggestion
open Nat Finset
```
and then you can remove `Nat.` and `Finset.` from lemma names later (there are lots of these)

```suggestion
/-- 
**Goldbach's theorem** : no two distinct Fermat numbers share a common factor greater than one. 

From a letter to Euler, see page 37 in [juvskevivc2022].
-/
```

golf:
```suggestion
  refine ((dvd_prime prime_two).mp h_m).elim id (fun h_two ↦ ?_)
  exact (odd_fermat.not_two_dvd_nat (h_two ▸ h_n)).elim
```

Lots of explicit arguments here can be inferred from context:
```suggestion
  have h_m : m ∣ 2 := (Nat.dvd_add_right <| (gcd_dvd_right _ _).trans <| dvd_prod_of_mem _ 
    <| mem_range.mpr hkn).mp <| fermat_eq_prod_add_two ▸ h_n```

`strictMono_nat_of_lt_succ` is only making your life harder here:
```suggestion
theorem strictMono_fermat : StrictMono fermat := by
  intro m n
  simp only [fermat, add_lt_add_iff_right, pow_lt_pow_iff_right (one_lt_two : 1 < 2), imp_self]
```
`n` should be an explicit argument here (and in all the other lemmas where it isn't inferrable from some other hypothesis, as in `odd_fermat`, `fermat_product`)

ok, fixed. 
I had kinda thought that if `fermat n` appears, it would be enough to infer it, but of course I suppose often it might appear not in this form, but just as number.

The general rule is that arguments can be implicit if they can be inferred from *other explicit arguments*, not from the type of the conclusion (with an exception for `Iff` lemmas when you can implicit things if they can be inferred from other arguments + the type of either half of the "iff").

```suggestion
theorem odd_fermat {n : ℕ} : Odd (fermat n) := 
  (even_pow.mpr ⟨even_two, (pow_pos two_pos n).ne'⟩).add_one
```

```suggestion
The Fermat numbers are a sequence of natural numbers defined as `fermat n = 2^(2^n) + 1`, for all natural
```

```suggestion
/-- Fermat numbers: the `n`-th Fermat number is defined as `2^(2^n) + 1`. -/
def fermat (n : ℕ) : ℕ := 2 ^ (2 ^ n) + 1
```

```suggestion
theorem coprime_fermat_fermat {k n : ℕ} (h : k ≠ n): Coprime (fermat n) (fermat k) := by
```

```suggestion
theorem coprime_fermat_fermat {k n : ℕ} (h : k ≠ n) : Coprime (fermat n) (fermat k) := by
```

Just noticed one extremely pedantic issue:
```suggestion
    (show 2 ^ 2 ^ n + 1 - 2 = 2 ^ 2 ^ n - 1 by omega), ← sq_sub_sq]
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/Fermat): Fermat numbers
